properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong northeast outflow winds gusting to 90 km/h have developed over the Fraser Valley as arctic air from the BC interior pushes out to the coast. These strong outflow winds will ease below warning criteria near noon, but winds will remain blustery. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-15T02:11:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-14T11:47:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1575999897.2020
Area: Fraser Valley - west including Abbotsford, Fraser Valley - central including Chilliwack
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong westerly winds gusting to 70-80 km/h will produce widespread blizzard conditions that will last through Sunday. At Sachs Harbour, gusts are expected to peak early Sunday morning, with gusts to 90 km/h possible. At Paulatuk, gusts are expected to peak early Sunday morning, with gusts to 120 km/h possible. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-15T08:22:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-14T16:23:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0544707103.2020
Area: Sachs Harbour, Ulukhaktok, Paulatuk, Tuktoyaktuk - East Channel Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A widespread and hazardous winter storm will affect the western Arctic until Sunday evening. Strong winds will produce poor visibility in blowing snow at times over some areas today and Sunday. Timing and severity remain somewhat uncertain, however conditions are expected to deteriorate Saturday night at Tuktoyaktuk. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-15T05:19:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-14T13:20:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3068582504.2020
Area: Tuktoyaktuk - East Channel Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:

At Sachs Harbour, gusts are expected to peak early Sunday morning, with gusts to 90 km/h possible. At Paulatuk, gusts are expected to peak early Sunday morning, with gusts to 120 km/h possible. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Additional snowfall: 5 to 10 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 50 km/h. Locations: Upper Lake Melville. Time span: continuing until overnight tonight. Remarks: Snow will continue today and tonight, and combine with gusty winds tonight to cause blowing snow at times. Conditions will improve before Sunday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-15T05:39:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-14T13:40:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4123686343.2020
Area: Upper Lake Melville
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An area of snow has moves into the Leader region overnight and will persist through Saturday. Snowfall totals for this event will be in the 5 to 10 cm range for most of the region. However, areas of higher terrain, or localities toward the Alberta border or the TransCanada Highway may see 10 to 15 cm of new snow before the snowfall tapers off Saturday night. Travellers should be aware that parts of the Cypress Hills, Montana, and southern Alberta will see much heavier snow with poor visibilities in snow and blowing snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-15T02:32:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-14T10:33:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3096968928.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A widespread and hazardous winter storm will affect the western Arctic until Sunday evening. Strong winds will produce poor visibility in blowing snow at times over some areas today and Sunday. Timing and severity remain somewhat uncertain, however conditions are expected to deteriorate Saturday night at both Ulukhaktok and Tuktoyaktuk. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Long lasting blizzard conditions are expected to persist into Sunday evening. Strong westerly winds, gusting 70-80 km/h will last through Sunday. At Sachs Harbour, gusts are expected to peak early Sunday morning, with gusts to 90 km/h possible. At Paulatuk, gusts are expected to peak early Sunday morning, with gusts to 120 km/h possible. Heavy snow is falling at Ulukhaktok and blizzard conditions will begin this morning. Conditions are expected to improve by Sunday afternoon. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h except 100 along parts of the coast. Locations: the Great Northern Peninsula. Time span: until near noon today. Remarks: Snow at times heavy and blowing snow will taper to flurries near noon. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-14T18:59:27-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Further snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Maximum wind gusts: near 80 km/h. Locations: Labrador Coast from Nain to Lodge Bay and inland to Eagle River. Time span: continuing until midday Sunday, except improving later today over southeastern Labrador. Remarks: The snowfall rates will be heaviest today and will combine with gusty easterly winds to cause widespread blowing snow. Snowfall rates will begin to ease in the southeast today and elsewhere tonight. The blowing snow is expected to persist into midday Sunday over many areas as the winds shift to strong northwesterlies. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-15T07:45:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-14T15:46:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3509589648.2020

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Gusty easterly winds will combine with cold arctic air to produce wind chill values near minus 35 for Yoho Park - Kootenay Park. Conditions will improve during the day but cold wind chills near minus 35 are expected to redevelop tonight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-15T08:54:04-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A blizzard has developed in the community of Kugluktuk and is forecast to end this morning, as winds ease slightly. However, it is expected that blowing snow will continue for the rest of today, reducing visibilities. Blizzard conditions are anticipated to return to the region Saturday night as winds turn northwesterly and increase. Blizzard conditions are expected to last into Sunday. Blizzard conditions have started at Gjoa Haven this morning. However winds should diminish there this evening and allow conditions to improve then. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-15T06:23:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-14T14:24:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1635230955.2020
Area: Kugluktuk, Gjoa Haven
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR BURNS LAKE (March 12, 2020 - Smithers) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has issued a Road Dust Advisory for Burns Lake because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation or dust suppression. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise near busy roads until the advisory is lifted. Exposure is particularly a concern for pregnant women, infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-03-15T00:59:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2020-03-14T11:45:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3234298025.2020
Area: Lakes District

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter weather conditions will affect parts of southern Alberta until this evening. Snowfall will continue into this evening for some communities, easing in the warned regions from west to east throughout the day. Northerly winds will cause reduced visibility in blowing snow, especially near the international border. By this evening, total snowfall accumulations may approach 20-30 cm, with regions in southwestern Alberta possibly reaching 40 cm. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter weather conditions will affect far southwestern Saskatchewan today. Snowfall will continue throughout the Shaunavon region today. Generally snow fall totals of 5 cm are expected but areas towards the Alberta border are likely to see snowfall totals of 10 to 20 cm . Gusty easterly winds will bring poor visibilities in snow and blowing snow during this period. The snow and blowing snow will weaken later in the afternoon and taper off this evening. Travellers should be aware that parts of Montana and southern Alberta will also be hit with this late winter storm. ### Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-15T07:59:10-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Cold arctic air moving southwards from the BC Interior will push out through Howe Sound this weekend. Northerly winds will gust to 80 km/h except to 100 near Bowen Island this morning and then diminish somewhat this afternoon. Winds will gust up to 90 km/h again near Bowen Island overnight and early Sunday morning. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-15T03:44:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-14T11:45:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3696916497.2020
Area: Howe Sound
properties.Author: Environment Canada
